As recorded by Steven Holmes of the New York Times in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” With prophetic clarity, Holmes foresaw the wreckage that lay ahead: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As the tale unfolds, it is apparent, as Holmes prognosticated, that these reckless lendings would indeed herald the unraveling of the economy.

The economy, like a great ship in storm-tossed seas, was beset by manifold perils, not least of which was the intricate web of mortgage structures newly conceived. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations—these tools of financial alchemy—were wielded with abandon in the years leading to the crisis, binding ever more tightly the fortunes of households and markets to the capricious housing sector. Thus did they overextend themselves, precariously perched upon the precipice, vulnerable to the slightest shift in the winds of price.

And so the bubble burst, and the institutions that had placed their faith in these mortgage-backed instruments were left to reckon with the wrathful void. The foremost investment banks of the nation reported their burdens of mortgage debts, a staggering $4.1 trillion, an amount that stood as a testament to folly, equaling a third of the nation's gross domestic product. In the denouement, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were cast off at a pittance, Lehman Brothers dissolved into the ether, while Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were compelled to don the mantle of commercial banks, shackled by the chains of regulation. Fannie and Freddie, laden with $5 trillion in mortgage debt, were enfolded into the embrace of government control come September of 2008.

The art of exposition, that treacherous landscape where the threads of a tale are laid bare, revealing the careful weave of a writer's toil. It is a place where a storyteller might soar, their words a tapestry pulling the reader into a world spun with a careful hand. Or it may be the very place where the reader's eyes grow heavy, and they seek escape through the turning of a page or the click of a button, cursing the creator's name, a lamentation echoed by the disgruntled murmurings of Dr. Merlin, who finds herself vexed by the overabundance of detail, a deluge of information drowning the senses.

Exposition, it stands there, indifferent, not a friend to the scribe.

The wise reader, versed in the adage "Show, don't tell," knows well the danger of slipping into the mire of endless prose, where action ceases and the weight of words suffocates. Dr. Merlin, despite her wisdom, finds herself ensnared in passages thick with exposition, where the narrative stagnates or overflows with a glut of history. It is the siren call, urging the writer to lay down the past in haste, to clear the path for what lies ahead, a temptation not unlike the whisper of another voice bidding the author to recount every minute detail of their characters' bygone days.

Exposition, the act of recounting the tale, often in the plainest of tongues. In the realm of cinema, it emerges when one character heaps upon another a torrent of revelations, reminiscent of the mariner's ancient tale. In the realm of fiction, it is the author who bears the burden of this telling.

Consider this: you are drawn into a story and are told that the heroine crossed paths with her beloved at a time and place, they wed in splendid fashion, and her husband met his end before her eyes. You would not expect this saga to unfold across mere pages, devoid of the voices and souls of those within. You would yearn for the author to linger upon the husband's essence, to reveal through his words and deeds the depth of his love, and you would wish for the heroine to display, in grand and subtle gestures, how his presence illuminated and enriched her world. Such depth would bind you to the husband's fate and unveil the heroine's heart, her vision of him, the strength of their union, the reflections of her spirit mirrored in his gaze. Thus, you would grieve his passing alongside her, and in doing so, find yourself entwined with her journey.

In essence, you crave flesh upon the bones of this simple tale: "They met, they married, he died."

As the weaver of stories, it falls to you to bestow that flesh. (*gazes upon the metaphor, sighs, and presses forward*) The temptation to hasten through events is ever present. Perhaps you introduce a new soul, once of the Air Force, now the guardian of a night-shrouded gas station, twice wed, childless, a fisherman of weekends, harboring dreams of ownership, and a taste for Eggs Benedict with the dawn.

In the half-light of an Ohio dawn, I watched the flickering screen relay its tales of woe and violence. Columbus, they said. NBC 4, live and urgent, August thirteenth, two thousand eleven. The lead story, a grim testament from Ashley, Ohio. A man named Shad Hostettler had taken to his wife with a blade, though her name remained unspoken, shrouded in the silence of the unsaid. His visage appeared, captured in a mug shot, a countenance carved from malice itself. They spared but two minutes for this grim development, the details sparse and raw. He had stabbed her, the cold metal biting flesh, and now sat shackled by the law. Two minutes seemed fitting for a tale still unfolding. 

Then came the tale of Travis Buyers, eighteen, a soul caught in the crosshairs of an early morning in Sharon Woods. A gunshot had felled him, left him clinging to life, while the streets whispered of shadows and secrets. The SWAT Team prowled, yet no man had been ensnared by justice. The brevity of this account was a bitter pill, a reflection perhaps of the world’s skewed gaze. A black man, a black neighborhood. How often are such lives glossed over, their stories fading like smoke? Were it a white child, a white soul missing or wronged, the clamor would rise like thunder. Yet here, silence reigned, a stark testament to the world’s indifference.

Next, they spoke of a gunshot wound etched into the skin of a Med-Flight helicopter. The air had borne a .22 caliber bullet, a silent messenger of malice. Crime-Stoppers, they said, would pay five thousand dollars for a whisper leading to the shooter’s capture. 

The sky promised rain and storms for the morrow, with temperatures lingering in the mid to low eighties. A whisper of weather, a siren call to keep the watchers tethered to the screen.

A robbery, too, on Clime Road, where shadows moved with intent. A dark-skinned man, they said, clad in a hoodie, six foot tall and a hundred fifty pounds. Their words lingered, dwelling on the darkness of his skin, the color of his deeds. 

Another tale, a man named Rene Rodriguez, bound in chains of his own making. A Texas drug-kingpin, weaving a web of marijuana from the south to Ohio. Twenty-five years in prison, they said, though the words came strange, three hundred months rolled off their tongues, a calculation meant to chill. Hispanic, they called him, a detail that seemed to matter little to his crimes yet was spoken nonetheless. 

And so the news ran its course, a river of stories flowing past, each one a reflection of the world’s fractured face.

In the vast and intricate landscape of financial instruments, there lies a creation known as the exchange traded fund, or ETF. It is a security crafted to mirror the movements of an index, a commodity, or a collection of assets, much like an index fund, yet it possesses the nimbleness of a stock, flowing through the exchanges like a current in a river. An ETF offers the broad embrace of diversification akin to an index fund, while bestowing upon its holder the singular advantages of stock ownership—selling short, buying on margin, the liberty to acquire but a single share. Though these lures are many and strong, the expense ratios of ETFs remain modest, markedly lower than those of mutual funds that roam the financial plains. Yet, it is not without its shadows, for each trade commands a commission, akin to the tolls exacted on stock orders. 

The allure of ETFs extends to the myriad funds they offer, each a new path to tread. But the wise investor knows the necessity of scrutiny, to ascertain whether the promises of diversification ring true and to what measure they do so. Thus, we turn our gaze to the ETF known as IHF, to pit it against the ten mighty holdings that form its core, seeking to unravel the truth of whether a solitary ETF can match the bounty of a diverse clutch of stocks, or if greater riches lie in a different weave of the same threads to yield a more optimal return or sharper ratio.

To navigate this quest, we must narrow our focus to the ten holdings that command 63.58% of the ETF's entire essence. Below, the ten holdings await, their share of the whole laid bare.

In our endeavor to grasp how these ten stocks embody the spirit of ETF IHF, we shall adjust the percentages of assets to a perfect hundred, calculating each stock's contribution to a portfolio's Beta and Return, were it composed solely of these ten in the proportion crafted by the ETF's architects. The figures of Beta and return, they rest within the chart below.

From this chart, a revelation emerges: a portfolio of these ten holdings yields a return 6.11% greater than the ETF itself, a 16% surge. The Beta of these ten is .12 beneath the ETF's own. Thus far, the signs suggest that a portfolio of these top ten could promise richer returns with gentler risk. Yet, we must consider the chance that the means of these two portfolios lie too close in statistical terms.

To discern whether these paths diverge truly, we must measure the standard deviation of each stock, adjusting them to a perfect hundred, comparing their collective sway to that of the ETF IHF.

Referring back to Figure 17, there was a steep decline in the submissions of commuter logs as the third month of the project drew on. A thing disheartening to behold, and elusive as the reasons might be. The onset of winter on a campus flanked by the stubborn bones of New England saw a dwindling of those who might venture forth by bicycle or stride, and thus some part of the decline might be accounted for. December, a month that signals the close of the fall semester, finds all absorbed in the fevered completion of assignments, the tallying of grades, and other such reckonings. The mere thought of filling out a commuter log might have slipped through the cracks of consciousness for many souls. Moreover, December heralds the advent of the holiday season's haste and the long respite for students and faculty alike, a time when the campus itself seems to draw a long breath and pause. Classes resume in late January for the spring semester, perhaps another piece of the puzzle to explain the scant logs of that month. Yet none of this elucidates the sparse submissions of February. One might surmise that any endeavor of this nature is bound to begin with a fierce spark of energy and enthusiasm, only to wane in its intensity. To counter this inevitable ebb, we inaugurated the Carpool Challenge Week, a concerted campaign in March, seeking to rekindle the spirit of the endeavor, which did see an upward tick in log submissions for that month. Thus, we faced the challenge of sustaining the momentum of the project against the natural pull of diminishing interest as well as the specific disruptions of holidays and semester breaks so common in academic life.

Another hurdle for this endeavor, or any such venture into alternative commuting, lies in the simple truth that people cherish the liberty and autonomy afforded by the steering wheel of their own vehicles. This love is etched deep into the heart of our culture. Hence, it is paramount to offer inducements to entice the populace toward alternate paths of commuting. We dispensed a multitude of prizes in the form of gift certificates to local eateries, coffeehouses, massage parlors, the town's independent bookstore, and even some larger national chains. Yet it would have been a curiosity to behold the impact on participation had the stakes been raised—perhaps with the offering of a fine bicycle, a hybrid vehicle, or an electric car. Such offerings might have served to stave off the decline in engagement that the project witnessed. The nature of the prizes remained unchanged throughout the course of the project. Yet, if the worth of these prizes had seen an increase as time wore on, it might have bolstered participation. The gift cards sufficed at the project's outset, but had we announced in December the inclusion of a pair of bicycles, and in January the prospect of a hybrid or electric car, one can only ponder how the tides of participation and engagement might have swelled instead of receding.

In the vast vaults of the Library of Congress, where the ghostly flicker of early Edison films lies entombed, I found myself drawn to the strange allure of the trick films, fifteen in all, spanning the years from 1895 to 1901. These curious relics, born of the early days of cinema, wielded the cutting edge of creative editing to conjure illusions that danced upon the screen. My study, with its gaze fixed upon their poetic essence, sought to unravel the threads that tied these spectral apparitions together and to glimpse the strange mutations that emerged in the later years. At the dawn of the twentieth century, the trick film was a creature of the stage, framed by the rigid proscenium, its movements confined to long and medium shots, bound by the iron law that one shot must suffice for one film. Yet, there were bold whispers of rebellion, of films that dared to splice together multiple shots, fracturing the old order.

What strikes the eye in these early trick films is the steadfast allegiance to the interior set, the camera an unyielding sentinel before the stage's proscenium. It does not stir, does not chase after men or things. This static composition, a vestige of theater and vaudeville's magic acts, was the common currency of the early cinematic world. The actors, like shadow puppets, moved only in the lateral plane, never venturing towards the camera's eye. Consider Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900). The players enter from the right, traversing the stage's breadth, and even as they slip from view, the camera remains, indifferent and unmoved.

The proscenium's dominion dictates that shots remain long, and at times, medium, but never close. In these films, the camera does not draw the actors near, does not peer into their eyes. It is an echo of the theater, where the audience beheld the full breadth of the stage, the actors' movements framed within its borders. In these embryonic days of film, the players lingered in the middle ground, the camera never beckoning them forth.

In the early days of trick films, the dictum was that one conceptual shot must suffice for a film. Such constraints kept most films brief, a minute or less, dictated by the frames per second. The narrative, too, was constrained, offering up vaudeville tricks— vanishing acts and transformations—with scant story to bind them. Yet, even within these confines, the illusion was crafted, a single "shot" in the viewer's eye often stitched together from many, weaving the magic of appearance and disappearance. Look closely at The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), an elder among trick films. In its deceptive simplicity, the attentive eye discerns the seam where Mary's "head" falls, an illusion spun from a single thread to the viewer's mind.

The Gothic novel, a paradox in itself, bears the weight of ages upon its back. Ian Watt calls it an "oxymoron for 'Old-New'," a strange concoction of time's passage rendered in letters. It stands both ridiculed and revered, accused of shallowness yet extolled for its capacity to invoke the 'terrible sublime' as Burke might whisper from the shadows. The genesis of this form, Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto, took ancient romance and the dawning modernity, weaving them into the fabric of the Gothic. Here, Walpole drew from the stage of yesteryears and the mimicry of nature found in novels newly birthed, calling forth "A Gothic Story" to mark the beginning of something not yet understood. 

The Gothic, a ghost from medieval theatre, architecture, and tradition, rose amidst a world that saw it as an echo of the past, crude and unsophisticated against the backdrop of modernity's march. Yet in its heart lies a fusion, the ancient's theatrical flair with the novel's intimate glimpse into the soul, a mingling that grants it the power to endure. It is this strange alchemy, this union of past and present, that allows the Gothic to stand timeless and yet fresh, a relic that renews itself in the eyes of those distanced by centuries.

Chivalry, one of the Gothic's most radiant ideas, shines through these narratives like the glint of armor in moonlight. The medieval knight, noble and steadfast, finds a place in The Castle of Otranto, where the ideals of chivalry are both preserved and transformed. To the Gothic scribe, chivalry was more than mere pageantry; it was a lament for an ideal, a mirror held up to a society seen wanting. Walpole, amidst a world of political turmoil, yearned for a return to the bravery and honor he perceived as lost. In these tales, the bygone era of gallantry is exalted, romanticized, a whisper of the Romantic movement yet to come, a plea for the present to be bettered by the past's virtues.

In Frederic, a character in Walpole's tale, the reader finds this chivalric spirit embodied. Before Frederic steps into view, his presence is felt, a tapestry of knightly images woven into his very essence. He is a prince, a soul marked by suffering, touched by tragedy, believed to have fallen to infidels. The figure of the "gallant and courteous Knight" is painted with broad strokes, an exaggeration that heralds the Gothic's penchant for excess, a precursor of tropes to be.

In the quiet dance of commerce, supply chain management moves goods upon the earth from the whisper of a customer’s desire to the raw sinews of material, through the loom and shuttle of supply, the forge of production, and out into the wide arms of distribution. It was in the year of our Lord nineteen hundred and eighty-two that a man named Keith Oliver, a seer in the world of consultancy, gave name to this ballet. He spoke of the grand orchestration, the laying down of plans, the execution, the reigns held firm and loose, all in service of the ever-hungry customer’s need, met with the swiftness of the hawk and the efficiency of the ant.

In the cosmos of supply chain, six stars shine bright: production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information. These are the tools of the trade, the compass by which a manager charts his course toward the shores of customer satisfaction.

Production, the first step, lays the foundation stone for the structure that is the supply chain. It is here the plans are drawn, etched into the earth and air. Here, managers peer into the depths of the market, the oracle that tells what the people crave. And when they see clearly what the people demand, they decide upon the goods to be born, and the number of those goods. Then, the question of where these goods shall take shape arises, which plant will best honor the balance of volume and quality in homage to the customer’s yearning. With this settled, the next focus is the meticulous scheduling of labor and the vigilance over the machines that hum and toil. Production is the cornerstone, each detail more precious than gold, for the lack of foresight here spells ruin, a wasteland of time and treasure lost. In the corridors of Wal-Mart and Target, I have seen the gospel of process laid out, each task a ritual from the stitching of uniforms to the arrival of the great trucks, the blueprint that guards against chaos and guides the hands of the workers.

The second star, supply, is a dance of strategy and partnership. Decisions made here carve out the soul of a facility, from which the bonds of outsourcing grow. A single product may be the child of many divisions, each with its own rhythm, its own tools and craftsmen. A manager must look upon these divisions and discern where each piece of the puzzle fits, or whether the hand of another company should be called upon. For outsourcing is a song of velocity, a swift river that promises quality and adaptability, all while holding fast to the promise of low cost, the lifeblood of the endeavor.

In the vast expanse of Victorian literature, there lies a meticulous tapestry of detail and the looming specter of aristocracy. Yet, two novels wander from this beaten path, Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights, each weaving a shroud of enigma and the peculiar, a departure from the ordered world of their contemporaries. This mystique breathes life into their cast, unfurling the depths of their desires and torments.

And thus, he was beset by a tumult of confounding visions, a fugue of the mind. He walked still in the company of Sikes and Crackit, their quarrels echoing in his ears, a phantom of his own devising, until he startled at the crack of gunfire. Cries pierced the tumult, lights danced before his eyes, and he was seized by some invisible force, borne away into clamor. In these fleeting specters ran the incessant ache of his being, a torment that gnawed at him without end. (Dickens, 220)

The novels wield this mystery through the lens of dreams or the fog of dreamlike reverie, the essence of which shifts with each telling. In Oliver Twist, these phantasms peel back the layers of the boy’s soul, revealing the shadows of his suffering and the truths he grasps at in the world around him. When the gunshot resurfaces in the 28th chapter, it strikes him anew in vivid recollection, as though he were adrift in a dream. The passage lays bare the frailty of his grasp on the events that engulf him, the peril of his condition mirrored in the spectres of Sikes and Crackit. The shooting consumes him, his senses dulled, the guiding hand unseen as it carries him away. He relives his despair, pain constant now and mingled with fear. The question of whose hand wrought his misfortune lingers, for it was not his own. This moment underscores his impotence, his inability to shape the course of his fate even as death looms near. A creeping resignation takes root, as if old Fagin's shadow had begun to fall upon him, pushing him towards a surrendering of spirit, numbing his will to fight. For surely, had he the strength, he would have struggled against the night that sought to claim him.

The day slipped through his fingers—a day? No day at all, vanished as soon as it came, and night settled once more, a night stretched in its terrible quiet, yet fleeting in its passing hours.

It was some years past that I found myself in the employ of an after school program where I endeavored to guide young minds through the murky waters of academic struggle. The children, their faces a mosaic of youth's hope and confusion, came seeking aid in sundry subjects, though my particular gift lay in the realm of English and the written word. It was there that one of the instructors beckoned me toward a young boy named Adrian, a lad perhaps in the third or fourth grade, who faced a peculiar plight with reading.

In those early days, it became apparent to me that something was amiss. Adrian could pronounce some letters with a clarity that was almost musical, yet others eluded him entirely, a riddle wrapped in the innocence of childhood. The boy, of Latino descent, spoke English with a fluency that belied his struggle, and we wrestled with the words until the day I met his mother. The encounter came one afternoon as I watched over some children left behind while the others ventured forth on a field trip. She entered, speaking only in the soft cadence of Spanish, a language I barely grasped.

Through this halting exchange, a realization struck, heavy and undeniable. Adrian could indeed read, but his acquaintance with the English alphabet was tenuous at best. Whether this insight served him well, I cannot say, but I harbor the hope that he now walks an easier path.

This tale, it serves to illuminate the chasm of language in the schools of California, a divide not always visible to the naked eye. Even a child whose tongue dances effortlessly through English can find himself stymied by its written form. We nod in agreement that this problem stands before us, a silent giant. What then, do we do?

For Adrian, the remedy was straightforward: guidance in the ways of English reading, the alphabet, and the sounds they conjure. Yet for those whose grasp of English is tenuous, the solution sprawls complex and multifaceted. There is no single path to redemption. Dual language systems, immersion, private tutors, ESL classes—none stand alone as the panacea. The answer lies in an amalgamation of all.

The dual language system, it holds promise not merely for those with Spanish as their mother tongue, but for all children. Studies whisper of its success, of children in such programs surpassing their peers. Yet fear circles this notion, a specter of wasted resources and unheeded benefits. But fear is a poor counselor. If these programs were to become the rule rather than the exception, all might flourish. 

How then do we proceed? Shall we insist on all teachers bearing the burden of bilingualism? No, such an expectation would be both unreasonable and unattainable. But there is no barrier to employing aides or tutors, those who walk the line between languages, guiding children across that divide.

In this lies the promise of a brighter future, where language ceases to be a barrier and becomes a bridge.

From the time we're small and the world is a vast unknowable thing, they tell us of forces greater than us. Unseen but felt in the marrow of our bones. Some learn of it beneath the steeple's watch, others in the quiet halls of temples, or deep within the chambers of their own hearts seeking answers. We take on the faith of our forebears as if it were our own skin, yet some cast it off, believing in nothing beyond the self, a universe of one. We may hold one creed and then trade it like a weathered coat for another. Each path is a journey into the self, a quest for light in the shadowed corners of our lives.

A cardinal, my father said, when I asked about his favorite bird. We sat on the porch, the rain drumming its relentless rhythm on the tin roof, smoke curling from our cigarettes. The gutters poured like small cataracts, drowning the plants at the porch's edge. His eyes were lost to the rain, a gaze that seemed to seek something that had long slipped from memory. He'd grown thin, his clothes hanging loose like old ghosts, his hair sparse as the winter trees. Still he looked into the falling rain, avoiding my eyes. I felt the solitude, the fear, the words lodged in my throat like stones. I would have told him how the thought of missing him was a specter I couldn't face. Instead, I hugged him, then sat closer, our eyes joined in the rain of a June twilight.

He left this world in December, five days past my twenty-second year. The chemo and radiation were cruel mercies, stretching his days beyond the doctors' reckonings but at what cost I could not say. What kind of God, I wondered, would allow such suffering. I uttered no prayers to the night. If God was there, he'd turned a deaf ear long before.

I could not bear witness as he crossed from this life to whatever lay beyond. I did not. I wished to remember him in life, not in the grasp of death. I knew him better than they, better than kin, and knew he would not have his child as a mourner at his passing. I curled into myself, a cocoon of grief, and waited three days for the news.

No one called. Not a soul.

In the dusty annals of American thought, there moves the figure of John Taylor of Caroline, whose spirit carried the banner of Republicanism with a fervor that burned as brightly as the sun upon the Virginia fields he so dearly cherished. His was a life bound to the earth, the soil itself a testament to his convictions, and though he wandered briefly into the corridors of governance, it was the land that shaped his voice, a voice unyielding in its call for liberty and the sanctity of self-rule. His creed was one of agrarian virtue, a truth he held as firm as the ancient oaks, and from this truth sprang his every utterance on sovereignty, the Constitution, and the machinations of the judicial realm.

To Taylor, the United States was a blank canvas, untouched by the hands of history, a place where the architects of governance could carve out a republic unfettered by the chains of old tradition. He placed his faith in the natural rights of mankind, rights intertwined like the roots of a great tree, where the loss of one would bring ruin to all, leaving naught but hollow echoes of what once was. These rights, he contended, stood as a bulwark against the overreach of government, a testament to the state of nature where strength and cunning prevailed, but which civilization must transcend.

In his vision of an ideal society, Taylor saw the necessity of a government that mirrored the dual nature of man, both noble and base. He held steadfast to a moral duality, proclaiming that the virtues and vices of governance were as human as the hands that wielded its power. Good principles, he asserted, were those that safeguarded the sanctity of property, nurtured the soil, and kept the specter of capitalism at bay. Such a government, he believed, would stand firm against the tide of avarice and self-interest that threatened to drown it, for self-interest was the clay from which man was molded—evil only when it birthed societies that fed upon the lives of others. The governance of man required vigilance, an ever-watchful eye to ensure that no malign principle took root.

Taylor, like his brethren in the Republican fold, held firm to a vision of the Constitution as a fortress with walls not to be breached by the expansion of Federal power beyond its written word. He saw the bloated Federal structure as a beast of burden, costly and prone to tyranny. Yet, he warned against a narrow reading of the sacred text, for without the light of its framers' intentions, such interpretation could lead to corruption. In his heart, it was the Declaration of Independence that stood as the true testament of the nation's soul, a proclamation of a union of sovereign states rather than a singular entity.

I looked downwards, my mind adrift in a void that took in the scene with a cold detachment. In silence, with a perception honed by habit, I observed without connecting the image to any lofty concept, my mind parsing the view before me with a mechanical grace. Thoughts came and went, fleeting as shadows, so fluid and seamless was my awareness that it seemed I had no thoughts at all, only the liquid witnessing of the scene presented to my eyes.

Once, on the counsel of an artist I knew, I had acquired a book on art titled The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. Since I was six, I had yearned to draw, and this book promised enlightenment from the nature of a pencil to the cerebral dance that gives life to lines. Among its teachings was a method of encircling any image with a square frame, thus reducing a labyrinth of detail—a bowl of fruit on a table in a kitchen that opened into a dining room—into a simple, graspable vision of that fruit sitting on a bare plane.

But now, as I looked down at the bowl before me, my mind failed to conjure that artist's frame. I stood overwhelmed, awestruck, able only to gaze in silent wonder. Picasso waded through his blue period, Monet painted his love for the green world, and the Italian masters scattered color like a benediction. If ever I aspired to claim the mantle of artist, here lay the inception of my canvas, the nascent chapter of my tale, Work in Brown.

My fingers touched upon the chosen instrument, muscles knotted and released as my hand moved through air, my mind's intent taking form in what could have been a moment of pure creation. Water swirled, smooth as a glassy river, clear and clean. Flakes of matter broke free, carried into oblivion. Muscles tensed and twitched, more anxious with each attempt, my hand struck the toilet handle again. Yet the stubborn brown bundle clung tight, like a slug to the bowl's surface.

Mop gripped with a lax hold, feet planted firm, tie chafing at my neck, I frowned at the impudent mass of waste left as a token for the fools tasked with cleaning Rite Aid's bathrooms. A few more flushes, a few more moments of quiet introspection, then my hand moved to the wall on my right, seized the end of the toilet paper, wrapping it around my hand until it resembled a mitt. Straightening, then bending at the waist, my hand dipped with slow inevitability into the bowl, like a mother reaching into an oven for the Thanksgiving bird...

In the waning light of day, the roads lay stretched out like a great indifferent web, ensnaring the young and unwary. The dust settles on the grave statistics of teenage fatalities behind the wheel, a grim testament to the collision of youthful exuberance and inexperience. The National Institutes of Health would tell you, as if in some somber sermon, that the adolescent mind is not yet tempered for the perils of the road. The raw inexperience of youth is a specter haunting the highways, leaving in its wake a trail of overturned vehicles, reckless speeds, and tragic departures from the pavement.

It is a folly compounded when youths gather in packs, the presence of peers acting like tinder to their impulsive fires. The Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center, in its cold arithmetic, reveals the tight bond between the age of passengers and the surge in traffic calamities. In response, California and its kin have erected barriers in the form of provisional licenses, curbing the hours and the company young drivers may keep.

Yet these measures, though well-meaning, seem but patches on a fraying quilt. The heart of the matter is that the youngest among us are ill-equipped for the burden of the wheel, as all evidence testifies. Psychologist Marvin Zuckerman, standing like a prophet in the wilderness, voices that even at eighteen, the mind may yet crave the thrill of risk. USA Today echoes his research, suggesting that this thirst for sensation does not truly abate until the cusp of twenty. Thus, it seems prudent to delay the bestowal of full driving privileges until this wild yearning finds its ebb.

Should we persist in our current course, the road ahead is fraught with the certainty of rising tolls. The children of the Baby Boomers will soon flood the driver's ranks, and the highways shall teem with their numbers. By 2010, a legion of new drivers will rise, a prospect that looms large with peril.

The path to remedy is as clear as it is necessary. Let the schools continue to sow the seeds of knowledge through driver's education, but hold the reins of power until the age of eighteen. Allow provisional permits, yet demand a testament of practical hours behind the wheel, perhaps mirroring the tally of states like California, with its call for six hours in instruction and fifty in supervised practice. Across this vast land, let there be a unified decree, a national safeguard to shield our youth from the harsh lessons of the road.

This proposition is no new revelation, but rather a call to reason in the face of gathering shadows.

In those quiet corridors of sound and silence, where the mind seeks to make sense of the world it hears, there lies a disorder as elusive as the whispers of the wind through barren branches. They call it Central Auditory Processing Disorder, CAPD, a specter of the auditory realm where the central nervous system falters in its duty to decipher the voices of the world. Herein, I shall lay bare its nature, its signs, and the ways in which a teacher might guide a child through the labyrinth of sound that is their classroom.

CAPD, a name that speaks with the authority of the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, marks a failure not of the ears but of the brain itself, a chaos in the kingdom of the mind where sounds are gathered and given meaning. It is not a deafness of the ears, for those afflicted hear as well as any other. It is the brain's inability to weave the tapestry of noise into the coherent cloth of understanding, where words are jumbled and conversations lost amid the clamor of the world.

In the annals of history, as early as the mid-1950s, the disorder found its first appellation, "auditory imperception." It was then the Italian minds of Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari began their quest to unravel this mystery, crafting tests to probe the minds of children who could not make sense of the sounds they heard. By 1961, Kimura entered the stage, wielding the tool of dichotic testing to chart the physiology of the auditory pathways.

The manifestations of CAPD are many and varied, like the facets of a well-cut gem. Those who bear its burden may find themselves adrift in a sea of sound, unable to pinpoint its source or separate its strands. They struggle with the subtle dance of voices, the rise and fall of speech that conveys more than mere words. One sound may drown another, a cacophony of meaning lost. Patterns and sequences dissolve into the ether, leaving naught but confusion in their wake.

To unveil this disorder, one must observe, like a tracker in the wild, the behavior of the afflicted. Audiologists, speech-language pathologists, and psychologists, with their battalion of tests and measures, seek to tease apart the threads of auditory skill. Yet no single test stands as a beacon of clarity, no cause can be pinned as the culprit. A patient is presented with a symphony of sounds, tasked with the impossible—to sift through the noise and find the melody. Advanced tests delve deeper, capturing the echoes within the ear, seeking the truth in the signals’ reply.

And so, we find ourselves at the edge of understanding, peering into the void where sound and silence meet, and where the mind struggles to make sense of it all.

In the pursuit of knowledge and the solemn duty of social work, my path is drawn toward the Division of Family and Children Services, where the wounded children of the world await the healing touch of those who would stand against the dark shadows of neglect and abuse. The craft of my intent is girded by values worn like armor: the service rendered, the respect earned, the ethics held high, and the unwavering resolve to mend the frayed bonds between souls. These are not mere tenets of the trade but echoes of my own heart's longing.

Once, I wandered that uncertain road, the way forward obscured by youth's indecision. High school and those early college days were a theater of flight and denial, where I bore witness to the human condition's frailty. It was the fall of 2009 when I left Piedmont College with a Psychology degree in hand, yet still adrift. A summer's day found me at a friend's door, where a boy of sixteen sat, bound in the silence of fear. His tale was one of escape, a flight from hands meant to cradle, not harm. The law, blind in its own way, offered no balm, and so I took it upon myself to speak with those who had birthed him. In their eyes, I saw a nervous dance of words, a litany of excuses for their son's cries for help. It was this encounter that lit the fire within me, a call to the blood to enter the realm of social work, to untangle the so-called "simple" disputes that weave through the fabric of family.

Justice, too, is a pillar of this calling. In this world, we speak of the individual with reverence, yet we bind ourselves with the chains of conformity. I have never been one to wear such shackles. My rebellion against injustice is painted in the colors of my hair, the piercings that adorn me, and the clothes that speak my truth. I stood with the GSBA, I stood against the scourge of racism, and I will continue to stand, a solitary figure against the tide of sameness. For justice is a flame that must be fed, and I am its keeper.

In the vast and shadowed corridors of human understanding, we find a paper that seeks to delve into the intricate webs of the Biological and Sociocultural models as they intertwine with the restless specter of insomnia. Herein lies the biological model, its gaze fixed upon the whispered secrets of our genetic lineage and the steadfast march of medical science. In contrast, the Sociocultural models cast their net wide, ensnaring the myriad tapestries of environment and their dance with race, ethnicity, and the arbitrations of society's structures. The examination that follows endeavors to unravel these models, illuminating each chosen piece of research as a beacon to clarify and expand upon these frameworks. The findings, though unveiled, are not beyond critique, as their strengths and frailties are laid bare.

In the realm of sleep, disorders stand as sentinels at the gates of rest, categorizing themselves as either primary afflictions of sleep, companions to other mental specters, or as echoes of deeper maladies. The primary disorders, known as Dyssomnias or Parasomnias, walk hand in hand with those that dwell in the shadows of Axis I or Axis II disorders. Yet others arise from the treacherous tides of medical complication or the siren call of substance. Within the Dyssomnias, we find Primary Insomnia, a foe to restful slumber, while Primary Hypersomnia stands as its mirror image, a challenge to the waking world. Narcolepsy, with its sudden surrender to cataplexy and the unbidden arrival of REM, joins this procession. Parasomnias, on the other hand, speak of nightmares and terrors, of somnambulistic wanderings, and of the unspeakable. This exploration turns its eye to insomnia, and by extension, the broader landscape of primary sleep disorders, through the lens of biological and sociocultural paradigms.

The biological model peers into the heart of sleep disorders, tracing their lineage through the genes and heritable factors, marking the physiological territories they claim. In the shadowed recesses of the hypothalamus, neurons bearing the standard of orexin govern the fragile balance of sleep and wakefulness. Through the lens of experimentation upon mice, the presence of phenotypic GABAB receptors upon these neurons is revealed, arbiters of the sleep-wake states. The GABAA receptor's activation whispers the promise of sleep, while its silence courts anxiety and restlessness, yet the GABAB agonist, baclofen, extends the mantle of slumber (Matsuki et al., 2009). These revelations hint at a genetic and environmental foundation for the GABAB receptor's role in the human condition. A deficiency or absence of this receptor might lead to a restless exile from sleep's embrace, bereft of medicinal aid. The sociocultural tapestry weaves a tale of inherited phenotypes, where alterations in the receptor's form could rend the fabric of one's sleep, casting shadows across the daily journey through school, career, and the mundane trials that demand unwavering focus.

For these two and a half years, four and a half semesters as they reckon it, I have walked the paths of University Park. A place sprawling and vast where to traverse from East Halls, where they set me down in my freshman year, across to Willard in the heart of it all, could take up to a quarter of an hour or more. The sky often darkened and brooding, the air thick with the promise of rain or snow, State College weather indifferent to the plight of its wanderers. An alum, not much older, told me once of the days when East Halls were remote, set apart by fields empty and unclaimed, now replaced by sports grounds, looming structures both of brick and steel, the Creamery and a health services edifice among them. The campus, ever expanding, maketh the journey longer and harder. 

In this world, the bicycle stands as salvation. Not the machine alone, but its rider, and a campus molded to its wheels. A friend, who had taken up cycling once more after years of neglect, told me of his rediscovered faith. "Bikes are great," he said, "once deemed uncool yet now the only way forward." His words echo true. Bicycling is a testament to efficiency, a bowl of oats and effort enough to take you miles. Now living off campus as many do, I find myself no closer than those dorm years past. A bike I did buy, the wisest choice made. The trek to Thomas building, otherwise a long and weary walk, now a mere five minutes if I push hard. Yet Pollock Road, the road of choice, is not always a simple path. 

Walking has its virtues, yet time is the master I serve. Without my bike, walking would be my only lot, a luxury I cannot afford. To Thomas and back each day would rob me of half an hour or more, hours within the week I do not possess. Time, a harsh steward, demands more than I can give.

In the dark terrain of Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World," there lies a silent indictment of the relentless march of technology and the cold machinery of capitalism that underpins it. A dystopia unfolds where the collective is exalted above the solitary soul, and from their first breath, the people are groomed to chase ephemeral joy, their lives a ceaseless pursuit of the next fleeting pleasure. They are but pawns on a vast board, their paths dictated by the unseen hand of the World Controller. Through the prism of Marxist theism, one discerns Huxley's quiet unease, a suspicion of the systems that rise like dark monoliths against the horizon of his time. Marxist whispers of homogeny and reification echo through the tale, a testament to Huxley's critique of the burgeoning economic order.

Within this satire of capitalism lies the specter of false consciousness, a Marxist thesis that ensnares the common folk, blinding them to the true nature of their bonds with those who toil alongside them. Their desires, their ambitions, all shaped by unseen forces, are but reflections of their own self-interest, a result of the ideological chains that bind the proletariat. In "Brave New World," this control is plain to see, inscribed in the very conditioning that molds the Deltas and Gammas. They wander through life without true volition, their minds sculpted by hypnopædia to consume, to spend, to indulge. The World Controller's hand guides them deftly, a puppet master unseen. Hegemony, the dominance of one class by another, is the silent architect of their fate. The lower classes, blind to their manipulation, partake in an ideology that props up the edifice of capitalism and consumerism, unaware of the chains they bear. Even the Alphas and Betas, aware yet indifferent, seldom rise above their ordained roles, save for the likes of Bernard who dare to question. In the interplay of social strata lies a somber reflection of capitalism's perceived oppression.

In this world, true connections are but a mirage. The novel draws no distinction among its populace, even its principal players are bereft of depth, shadows cast upon the wall. Huxley perhaps suggests that in the union of technology and capitalism, man is stripped of his agency and voice. Love, that most profound of emotions, is absent, as are the extremities of feeling; interactions are mere shadows on the surface, evident in the men's superficial appraisals of women, reduced to their pneumatic allure, and the women's unreserved recounting of their liaisons. The unquestioning acceptance of each class in the societal order mirrors the capitalist impact on the soul. Their unwavering adherence to their roles in the grand design speaks to the Marxist view of the proletariat, deceived into believing their supremacy, as long as they continue to consume, to conform, to walk in step with their brethren.

It was near four years past when I found myself in the halls of CBC, enrolling in a course on Islam. The room, charged with fervor, turned often to the debate on whether Islam holds hostility at its core. This query, it seems, swells in significance with each passing year. In the shadow of that day in September, I have watched the shifting tide of mass media's gaze. Once, it bore a scornful eye upon Islam, yet now it seems to bend toward a curious tolerance within the American landscape. Such a time, back in 2001, seemed unlikely for a man like Barack Obama, whose name alone whispered of a Muslim lineage, to vie for the highest office in the land.

The life of the Prophet, as told in biography, captivates me still. For what I have gathered of Muhammad's historical saga contradicts those words. I had held the belief that Muhammad wielded force in spreading the faith, that he overtook tribes and imposed Islam upon them. Yet the biography paints him as a martyr, a figure misread, who lowered himself in humility before others. In this telling, his teachings shone like a beacon, drawing seekers to him, one soul at a time.

There are echoes too, between Christ and Muhammad, in the tales of their deeds. Most striking is that of the mutton and milk, multiplied for forty men. Such writing aims to cast Muhammad in the light of a humble prophet, whose life was steeped in truth and miracles that needed no heralding. This, to me, is a perilous fallacy, for it diminishes the miracles and life of Jesus Christ. It is as if they seek to borrow from the legacy of Jesus, to fashion Muhammad in a similar mold.

Within the biography's pages, stories abound that seem intent on proving conversion to Islam as a spontaneous, witnessed truth. Yet these accounts often drift through third-hand tellings, a trail of whispers through unnamed voices. This weakens their claim, casting shadows of doubt upon the tales they mean to affirm.

What unsettles me most is the portrayal of Muhammad as a godly man, adorned with humility and wisdom. History’s account stands at odds with this image of gentleness. And I wonder if those who follow Islam today understand the true nature of Muhammad’s ascent to power.

In the dust and shadows of history, there was a man who walked the earth with teachings that burned bright for a time and then were left behind, eclipsed by the forward march of doctrines and edicts that bore his name but not always his spirit. The story of Christianity is one that ebbed and flowed, a river of belief carving new paths, straying farther from the headwaters of its origin. And here we stand, in a world shaped by the hands of progress, where the old and the new clash like titans. The traditional ones, rooted deep in their certainties, resist the winds of change. Yet the tide of history is a force relentless. Among the faithful, a stirring begins, a quiet murmur of awakening that will swell to a roar. A yearning to peel back the layers of time, to glimpse the face of the man they call Jesus, unadorned by the trappings of centuries. It is a path long and winding, a journey that may span decades or even centuries, but it is a path that must be walked. For the pendulum of time swings ever back, and the church, that grand old ship, will sail with it, stripped of its barnacles, towards the simplicity of its inception. 

The world will see a strange thing, a reversion, as if the clock itself had turned its face to the past. Denominations and divisions, those walls built by human hands, will crumble into dust. The tapestry of Christendom, once vibrant with colors and patterns of diversity, will be woven anew with threads of unity. It is a tale as old as time—empires rise and fall, the persecuted become the powerful. The land of the free, that once knew the chains of slavery, now stands with leaders born of those who were once bound. And so it will be with the faith that bears the mark of the cross. The great reversion will sweep through the churches of the West, a reclamation of the past, a return to the source. 

But to walk this path, the words of Jesus must be read not as edicts carved in stone but as stories whispered on the wind, metaphors dancing in the firelight. For what is it that has transpired since the man from Nazareth walked the earth? In the beginning, there was only the people of the covenant, the children of Israel. A single God looked down upon them, a divine whisper in the wilderness. By the time the Romans cast their shadow over Jerusalem, the Jews had splintered into factions—the Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, and Zealots, and the common folk who walked the roads between. And from these roots sprang a faith that would shake the world, a faith that must now find its way back to the garden.

In the deep recesses of the human soul, there lies a darkness, a greed, a self-centeredness that The Jungle lays bare. Here is the tale of men who care nothing for their fellows, those who strive only for their own prosperity while the world beneath them withers. Upton Sinclair paints this canvas with the owners and overseers of those vast factories, their gaze fixed solely on the growth and grandeur of their enterprises. Their eyes are blind to the lives they trample, the lives consumed by their relentless advance. The line of buildings stands stark against the sky, chimneys reaching heavenward, dispensing their blackened breath across the earth, a testament to the desolation wrought by the uncaring hand of progress. Sinclair's words show a world where the great smoke rivers and waste runoff poison the land and its creatures, yet the masters of these edifices remain indifferent to the ruin they sow.

In this desolate landscape, the workers toil, mere cogs in the machinery of wealth. For the few coins saved, the masters would sacrifice a multitude. From top to bottom, the enterprise is a cauldron of envy and spite, devoid of loyalty, a place where humanity is weighed against the dollar and found wanting. Hours stretch unending, and without a whisper of warning, they are cast aside, left to fend for themselves in a world without mercy. The time of The Jungle knew little of law or protection for those who labored, and thus the overseers drove their workers mercilessly, heedless of the wretched conditions imposed upon them. No words are spoken of it, yet the truth is laid bare; those who labored and died in Packingtown bore their burden in silence, with no refuge from the squalor of their labor or their lives. No agency nor savior was there to guide these lost souls, and though unions rose from their ranks, they too were wolves in sheep's clothing, profiting from the very ones they claimed to protect. In this place, men were bound as slaves, "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery."

In the dusky corridors of literature, there stands the figure of Edgar Allan Poe, his pen a whisper in the gathering gloom. Among his creations, "Dream-Land" lays claim to a peculiar foreboding, a self-proclaimed beacon of his poetic prowess. It is here that Poe summons the specter of "Thulé," a word that Mabbott, like a patient archaeologist, traces back to Virgil's hand. Virgil, who spoke of an isle beyond Britain’s shores, where the world’s map unwound into the unknown. Yet, the echoes of "Thulé" do not end in antiquity. They find voice anew in the Germanic echoes that stirred Poe’s soul.

In the shadowed recesses of Poe’s mind, Goethe's specter lingers, a testament to affinities unspoken. Karl J. Arndt, in his scholarly tome, draws lines between Poe's verse and Goethe's song, suggesting an imitation that is less mimicry than homage. Goethe, the bard of "Faust," whose drama was birthed in two acts, the first in 1808, and the second, an elegy in the year of his death, 1832. Within "Faust's" twilight verse lies "The King of Thulé," a tale of loss and desolation. A king, haunted by the ghost of a queen, driven to drink and despair, casting his last keepsake into the sea before he too succumbs to the void.

The king in Goethe’s poem and the specter in Poe’s "Dream-Land" seem reflections in a darkened mirror, each a shadow of Poe’s own lamentations. The drink, the loss, the burden of memory—these are the threads that weave their tapestry across the chasm of time. In the year 1842, a scant breath before Poe's invocation of Thule in "The Pit and the Pendulum," Grattan recast "Faust" into a drama of romance, igniting anew the flames of Goethe’s influence.

Twice Poe whispers of Thule in his collected works, his voice a distant echo. In "The Pit and the Pendulum," "ultima Thule" becomes the boundary of despair, while in "Dream-Land," it is both the beginning and the end. The landscape of Thule is painted with shadows, a desolate echo of Goethe’s king, bereft and adrift in a colorless purgatory. It is as if Poe has stepped into Goethe's world, finding there a kindred darkness.

Goethe’s presence in Poe's world is undeniable, a shadow cast long and deep by the reverberations of Tennyson's admiration. In the echoes of Tennyson’s praise, Poe found the call of Goethe’s work, resonant in the myriad reproductions that followed the original publication, each a stone cast into the literary waters, rippling outward toward eternity.

In the lawbound expanse of California, where the sun bakes the earth and men grapple with consequence, a question arises. Could one, having slipped upon a spill of applesauce in a grocery store, find justice in the form of punitive riches, claiming the storekeeper turned a blind eye with malice nesting in his heart, having twice heard of the mess and left it unattended while he dined? The judge, solemn and inscrutable, may not cast aside Jennifer Palmer’s plea for punitive redress. To carve out such a claim, evidence must be laid bare that the store’s keeper had acted with willful neglect, conscious of the harm his inaction might unleash, and that his deeds carried the stench of the despicable. Palmer might just weave her tale with the thread of Martin’s knowing. How he, like a man deaf to warnings, ignored the peril of the slick floor despite the injuries of others who fell before her. A tale of neglect, woven with the threads of prior mishaps, five in number, marking the year of our Lord two thousand and nine. 

On the thirteenth day of October, as the clock marked five in the evening, young Rich Wayne, keeper of aisles, spoke to Paul Martin, his superior, of applesauce spilled. Martin, engrossed in his repast, dismissed the tidings with a wave, claiming no time for the grievances of the shopping folk. A quarter hour passed, another voice, that of Mary J. Haddigan, echoed the warning, only to meet the same indifference. At half past five, the fates conspired, and Palmer, her steps unsteady, found herself upon the floor, her back bearing the brunt of misfortune. She now seeks recompense and punishment for her suffering, and the deliberation turns to whether to contest her claim for punitive relief. 

In the sun-drenched realm of California, the law speaks of punitive recompense for breaches not born of contract, where the defendant’s actions bear the mark of “oppression, fraud, or malice.” So it is writ in Cal. Civ. Code, § 3294(a) (Lexis 2010). Malice, the code declares, is a deed either meant to harm or one so vile it defies intent, carried out with conscious disregard for the rights or safety of others. In the annals of law, deeds earn the label of malice when the perpetrator, aware of the peril his actions portend, chooses willfully to walk the path of neglect, as noted in Taylor v. Super. Ct. of Los Angeles Co., 598 P. 2d 853, 856 (Cal. 1979).

She had always carried within her a yearning, a want that lay like a stone in the gut, unyielding and unfulfilled. It had begun its quiet existence when she was but fourteen, stepping into the uncertain corridors of her teenage years. And there it remained, steadfast and unrelenting, even as she stood on the cusp of seventeen. In the passage of those years, she discerned that it was not a thing she sought but a someone, yet the boys who circled her world failed to stir her heart. They had tried, some driven by the hopeful folly of youth to sway the unswayable, yet none could hold her gaze. She wondered at this, questioning the strange emptiness that lay within her, pondering what manner of mystery it was that held her separate from the common desires of her age. Her ruminations, spanning years, had conjured theories but none that could satisfy the gnawing question. And so, she moved through life, ever questioning the nature of her desire.

Her home was a place of peace, a sanctuary marked by the quietude of her parents, who were good and steady folk. Their lives were seldom marred by discord, and arguments with their daughter were a rare occurrence. The only friction arose from her burgeoning independence, her spirit unfurling like a banner against the calm backdrop of their lives. She was their daughter, yet her vibrant nature was a counterpoint to their serene existence, a testament to her kindness and the light she carried within.

Yet today, the calm was shattered. As she wandered from room to room, seeking some muse for her restless heart, a sharp cry reached her from the kitchen, her mother's voice cleaving the air. Panic set her to motion, her feet carrying her swiftly to the source of the sound. "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" she cried, her voice edged with fear. There lay her mother, crumpled upon the floor, her breath coming in pained gasps, each exhalation a whispered "Ow." The daughter knelt beside her, hands gentle and seeking to aid. "Ouch ... swee - ty, I ... need you to take me to - the hospital." Her words were forced, squeezed between the shards of pain, and her daughter knew the urgency was real. "Okay Mom, just tell me where I can pick you up." Her mother guided her, and in that moment, the daughter felt a surge of gratitude for the strength she had honed. Carefully, she lifted her mother, bore her to the car, and laid her in the back before setting out for the hospital.

The hospital loomed, a place thick with the scent of antiseptic and the quiet hum of fear. But her senses were dulled to such things, her mind tethered to the singular focus of aiding her mother. She carried her swiftly inside, her voice rising to call for the attention of those who could help. Faces turned towards her, concern etched in their lines, and a bed was swiftly brought forth to bear her mother away. They whisked her into the depths of the hospital, and the daughter was left to wait, her heart heavy with worry.

It was a fall from a stepping stool, an ascent made in pursuit of a vase perched high in the cabinet, that had felled her mother so.

In the silence of the study, figures and lives lay etched upon the paper like the dust of time. Here was the tale spun from the Mediterranean sun, a diet rich in the earth's bounty, its fruits and grains and nuts, a testament to the ancient ways. They called it the aMed diet, a variant of the old world’s sustenance, marked by its embrace of plant over beast, the lean flesh of fish, and the oil of the olive, shunning the saturated fats that spoke of indulgence. A draught of wine was not forbidden.

The past had whispered of this diet's promise, of lives prolonged and hearts spared from the ravages of disease. Yet the specter of stroke and its deadly claim had not been fully reckoned in these tales. Here now was a gathering of women, 74,886 strong, ranging from the ages of 38 to 63, their lives woven into the fabric of a grand design, the Nurses' Health Study. From 1984 to 2004, six times over, they bared their habits upon the scrolls of food frequency questionnaires.

Their stories were not left to chance. More than 95 percent stayed the course through these years. Their accounts were checked against the grim tally of medical records and death's own papers. Some tales were left to the realm of the probable, yet still they were heeded, numbers given voice in the absence of certainty.

To temper the whims of chance and capture truth from the passing years, scores were tallied, averaged over time. The shadows of confounding truths were cast aside, adjusted for age, and the many facets of living—smoking, body mass, the ebb and flow of hormones, and the elixir of multivitamins. Even the vigor of their days was counted from 1986 onward.

In the end, the numbers spoke. The path of the aMed diet bore fruit in the reduction of heart's malady and the silent thief, stroke. Across two decades, 2391 tales of heart's strife and 1763 of stroke were recorded, while the shadow of death claimed 1077 lives. For those who followed the diet most faithfully, the risks were lessened, a relative risk of 0.71 whispered to those in the lowest quarter.

Thus was the story told, of the Mediterranean's promise carried across the oceans to these women, the legacy of ancient wisdom, its truth laid bare in the numbers.

The sign stood there in the dim light as if it were some ancient relic unearthed in the heart of a city unyielding to time. Hitler is alive in Burma, it declared in stark black letters. A girl stood beneath it, Ellen Page they called her, once the star of a film named Juno, a solitary figure on a street corner of this world. Her hands clasped the cardboard where the haunting words lay inscribed with the indelible mark of a Sharpie. Burma, or Myanmar as they sometimes call it, a land in the clutches of a ruthless junta that seized power in the year of our Lord 1962 through the cold machinations of a coup d’état.

In the year 2007, the streets bore witness to an uprising not seen in a decade. Monks, draped in robes of saffron, took to those streets and gave name to the revolution. Their chants and prayers rising into the ether, the Saffron Revolution it came to be known. The people, stirred by the courage of the monks, found their voices and joined the march. At first, the government watched the gatherings with disdainful eyes but allowed them to persist. Soon enough, it spiraled into violence, the monks and the junta locked in a struggle that bore the bitter taste of war. The military stormed monasteries, leaving ruin in their wake. Journalists from foreign lands became prisoners, their freedom a distant memory. A man named Kenji Nagai, a lensman from the land of the rising sun, fell on the streets on the twenty-seventh day of September for the crime of witness.

The official tally told of thirteen souls lost, but a man named Colonel Hla Win, who broke ranks and spoke out, whispered of thousands who had perished, their bodies hidden from the world’s eyes.

Such tales are old as time itself. The lust for power and the silencing of dissent have shadowed human civilization since its dawn. Emperors of Rome proclaimed themselves chosen by the heavens to wield absolute power. In Japan, emperors were deemed divine, sent to guide their people through the tides of time. Across the seas, a president named George W. Bush sought counsel from Ted Haggard, the voice of those they called the Stupid People Worldwide, a faction of the Republic Party.

History is littered with echoes of such darkness. In 1989, in a place called Tiananmen Square, a gathering of students and workers and thinkers stood against the iron hand of authority. Their numbers fell to the ground, the truth of their loss hidden in the shadows of conflicting accounts. The genocide in Rwanda in the 1990s, where the Hutu, with government aid, unleashed death upon the Tutsi and any who sought moderation. And the world still shudders at the memory of the Third Reich, when lands across Europe were soaked in the blood of innocents, for they were deemed unworthy by a man whose name the sign now bore.

These tales, these truths, they linger in the air like the scent of smoke from a fire long extinguished yet never truly gone.

In the vast expanse of jazz, Duke Ellington carved his legacy as a man who understood the flow of time and the subtle power of sound. His orchestra was a canvas upon which he painted with the deft strokes of a composer who knew the weight of silence and the strength of a single note. The piano, his quiet companion, whispered in his compositions, but it was through his orchestration that Ellington truly spoke. His works were intricate tapestries woven from the threads of individual talents, each musician a color in his grand design. He built spaces where soloists roamed free, yet always within the embrace of a tightly knit framework. In this, he found a way to let the orchestra sing as one, its voice unique to each piece, a testament to his genius.

The Grove Music dictionary holds up Creole Love Call as a moment in time where Ellington turned voice into instrument, casting it into the flow of jazz. Without words, the voice added texture, a color that deepened the whole. In this slow, deliberate blues, Ellington's genius lay in his ability to mirror the style of his soloists, a skill that danced through his career like a shadow. Six choruses unfold, each a testament to his craft:
The first chorus, a call and response, voice and reeds entwined, begins smooth as a river before the current shifts to rougher waters.
Then the trumpet, muted, sings a melody that bends and sways with the blue notes.
A clarinet soars in the third, its high register backed by the whisper of syncopated piano.
The fourth chorus echoes the first, the full band rising in a brass and reed dialogue.
The fifth reaches a climax, a call and response that climbs to the heavens, lifted by the brass and rhythm's syncopated heartbeat.
Finally, the sixth returns to the beginning, voice and reeds speaking in growls, the voice now an instrument in its own right.
A brief tag ends it all, a vocal run and a trombone's dissonant farewell.

Ellington's use of voice added a hue to his work, a stylistic thread that ran deep. In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year hence, his mastery of orchestration and tone color shone bright. A dialogue between "Bubber" Miley's muted trumpet and Baby Cox's scat singing blurred the line between voice and instrument, crafting a sound both rich and whole. It Don't Mean a Thing (If It Ain't Got That Swing) carried these ideas forward, with Joe "Tricky Sam" Nanton's muted trombone leading the way into the melody's heart. Ellington's orchestra, his creation, swung with a life all its own.

In the vast and unyielding theater of life, one might ponder the reasons why creatures shift and change in the manner that they do. What unseen chains bind them, directing the course of their transformation through time’s relentless passage? As early as 1917, D’Arcy Thompson mused that “Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms,” a sentiment that echoes through the present age. In recent years, an attempt has been made to apply the rigors of mathematical modeling to the arc of mollusk skeletogenesis, tracing the lineage both through the life of the individual and the lineage of its kind (see Raup and Stanley, 1981). Our inquiry ventures into this realm, employing mathematical constructs alongside experimental endeavors to unravel the mysteries of evolutionary-developmental change in Prunum. Through the lens of X-radiography, we have sought to distill the essence of these creatures, extracting parameters to simulate their form, both imagined and real. Into the alchemy of software named CerioShell (Stone, 1995), these parameters were cast, conjuring shells of hypothetical morphology that mark the borders of conceivable change in Prunum. Such findings are married with experimental and descriptive studies to cast light upon the grand tapestry of macroevolutionary events within this clade.

Consider the shell, a winding structure that charts its existence in a spiral dance through the corridors of time and space. These turns, these revolutions of a coiled shell, are known as whorls, spiraling around a phantom axis that threads its way through the shell’s core, the columella. The expansion of whorls is a variable thing, marked by a slender line of division known as the suture. In most shells, the grandest whorl is the last, the body whorl. All preceding it belong to the spire, with the apex crowning the spire’s peak, and its opposite end termed the base. Through the aperture, the creature within emerges into the world.

A shell may be viewed from multiple angles: apical, basal, apertural, and abapertural. And yet, the conventional stance is apertural, with the aperture facing forward, apex reaching for the sky.

To count whorls, one begins with an apical view, seeking the birth of the first suture. A line is drawn, slicing the shell into two halves. From this line, whorls are counted, measured to the quarter.

The shell’s form is a sequence of apertures, a journey through temporal and spatial dimensions as the creature builds its home. The path of the aperture can be traced by the center coordinates of each whorl’s aperture and its radii, horizontal and vertical. 

This trajectory is not only a thing to be seen but one to be captured in the language of math. Once captured, the parameters may be altered, the skeletogenesis of the mollusk modified, a testament to the dance of numbers and nature.

In the archipelago of Indonesia, the shadows of mortality cast long and unchanging over the tender lives of the newborn and the very young. A decade has passed and the numbers stand defiant, unmoved. The nation strides the path of many a Millennium Development Goal, the waters cleansed, the sanitation improved, yet the specter of child and maternal health looms still, untouched by the winds of progress needed to reach the fabled goals of 2015. The roots of this stagnation are myriad and entwined, and they tell a tale of a health system in need of fortification, a shift from fleeting programmatic interventions to foundations strong and enduring.

Upon the land, some progress is etched in the sand. Seventy-two in every hundred births now witness the presence of skilled hands, though the term is broad and inclusive of those traditional midwives whose skillset halts at the threshold of complication. Thus, hemorrhage looms large, a grim reaper at the gates of life. The numbers tell a story, yet deceive, for the progress is but skin-deep and the journey yet long. Furthermore, the children, under five and struck by the scourge of diarrhea, find less solace in the hands of a professional healer than before. The tale of postnatal care is one unwritten, incomplete, yet the whispers speak of neglect and lowly rates across the land.

In the realm of Cesarean births, the numbers are stark, a meager 4% where more should stand. The divide yawns wide, urban settings claiming 7%, rural a paltry 2%, a testament to the chasm of equity that cleaves the country in twain. Access, a cruel mistress, favors the cities and shuns the country fields. The poor, burdened by the weight of cost, find the gates of healthcare closed, a gap of 27% between the richest and the poorest, a tale of disparity and woe.

As the nation ponders the path ahead for the care of mother and child, a question lingers, unyielding: how best to bridge the chasm of service? Shall the path be one of programmatic focus, or shall the health system be fortified in its entirety, casting a wide net over pre and postnatal care? The allure of targeted interventions beckons, their aims clear, their results swift. Yet beware, for the price is steep. The focus on one may leave others barren, resources drawn to the flame of funding, as the family planning sector learned under the shadow of HIV/AIDS. Parallel programs spawn duplication, uncoordinated, a tangle of forms and papers, a bureaucratic mire.

Thus the way is fraught, the journey long, and the choices many. Yet the path must be chosen, for the lives of the young and their mothers call out from the shadows, in need of light.

In the long passage of a century, popular music has unfurled its banners to include a legion of genres sprawling across the landscape, each a tributary of sound and rhythm that defies cataloging, a wild river that knows no bounds. It is a tangled web, this world of music, where even the simplest of tunes finds itself split into myriad subgenres, each a child born of the same primal cadence that echoes through time. Among them stands heavy metal, a colossus of sound that in the past forty years has carved its own path through the wilderness, a path both rugged and expressive, a testament to the myriad shades of the human soul.

Heavy metal, it is said, wears its heart upon its sleeve, its emotions unbridled and raw, a symphony of shadows that dances within the dark recesses of our being. The inception of this genre was but a whisper, yet it grew with a fervor that could not be contained, each branch of its lineage spawning yet another, and so on, until the very notion of what it is became as elusive as smoke on the wind. Today, the tree of heavy metal stands tall and wide, its branches reaching into the heavens, each limb a story of its own, each leaf a note that resonates with those who seek its truth.

The essence of metal is not merely in its sound but in its very being—a movement rather than a mere genre, a force driven by a darkness that is at once frightening and mesmerizing. It is a music of excess, of more, always more—more bass, more volume, more of everything that pushes the boundaries of what music can be. Those who dwell in its embrace are masters of their craft, wielding their instruments with a prowess that speaks of countless hours spent in pursuit of the perfect note. And yet, this movement, born in part from the haze of psychedelia, carries with it the shadows of its inception—a time when the world turned inward and the music turned outward, reaching for the stars with hands stained by the earth.

It is a music that revels in its own darkness, a visceral experience that speaks to the core of what it means to be human. It draws from the well of Romanticism, a dark mirror reflecting the soul's deepest yearnings. The lyrics, often dark and foreboding, are the very heart of this movement, a testament to the pain and beauty that coexist within us all.

Consider, if you will, the song "Helter Skelter," a piece from the Beatles that dances on the edge of this abyss, a response to the Rolling Stones that sought to claim the heaviness as their own. It is a song that teeters on the brink of madness, a dance with the devil that echoes through the corridors of time. Within its strains lie the roots of what would become heavy metal, a genre not born of light but of shadow, a testament to the human spirit's unyielding desire to explore the darkness within.

In the quiet years before the Surrealists cast their visions onto canvas, there was Henri Rousseau, moving with a deliberate grace through the landscapes of his own dreamscapes. The Dream, born in 1910 from the hands of this Post-Impressionist, spoke of wonder—a woman adrift in a land not her own but one that lived in the recesses of her dreams.
